title: Marlon Pius G. Pamplona, RMT
text:
A genomics specialist at the National Reference Laboratory for Influenza and Other Respiratory Viruses in the Department of Virology of Research Institute for Tropical Medicine. As the pioneer staff of the Influenza Genomics Team, he has been involved in building the NRL’s influenza genomic surveillance program from the ground up, optimizing sequencing protocols, testing bioinformatic workflows, automating data analysis, and establishing reporting standards.
He gained his foundational skills in data science through the PROJECT SPARTA scholarship of the Development Academy of the Philippines, and further strengthened his genomics expertise through a bioinformatics internship at the Philippine Genome Center. Marlon has also completed several WHO-supported trainings in viral genomics and genomic epidemiology, which broadened his capacity to support national surveillance efforts.
He provides technical assistance and capacity-building support in molecular techniques to sentinel sites and other National Reference Laboratories of the Department of Virology, and mentors colleagues in bioinformatics and data analysis. Marlon is currently pursuing a Graduate Diploma in Computer Science at the University of the Philippines Open University.

title: Niña Natalia L. Bautista, MD
text:
An Anatomic and Clinical pathologist who currently serves as Medical Specialist II at the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine under the Advanced Molecular Technologies Laboratory and a Medical Specialist III and Head of the Microbiology Section at the Philippine Children’s Medical Center. 
Dr. Bautista completed her postgraduate diploma in Molecular and Diagnostic Pathology at The University of Hong Kong and earned her Doctor of Medicine degree from Saint Louis University, with a bachelor’s degree in Biology major in Genetics from the University of the Philippines Los Baños. Her special interests include molecular diagnostics, clinical microbiology, digital pathology, and translational medicine, with active involvement in infectious disease diagnostics, including HIV.

title: Desiree D. Argana, MD
text:
A Pediatric Infectious Disease Specialist currently serving as a Medical Specialist III at the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM). Within the institute, she holds a pivotal leadership role as the Deputy Head and Quality Circle Head of the Department of Microbiology.
She established her medical foundation at the University of Santo Tomas, where she completed both her Bachelor of Science in Medical Technology and her Doctor of Medicine degree. She went on to pursue her residency training in Pediatrics at Manila Doctors Hospital and completed her subspecialty fellowship training in Pediatric Infectious Disease at the University of the Philippines – Philippine General Hospital (UP-PGH).
Dr. Argana is a Diplomate of both the Philippine Pediatric Society (PPS) and the Pediatric Infectious Disease Society of the Philippines (PIDSP). She is actively engaged in organizational service at PIDSP, where she serves as a member of the EREID, Socials, Multimedia, and Quiz Bee Committees.

title: Louis Andrew M. Olazo, RMT, MSMT
text:
Currently serves as the Section Head of the Learning and Development Section of the National Tuberculosis Reference Laboratory (NTRL). He leads the delivery of diagnostic training programs that strengthen the technical capacity of the country’s TB laboratory network. He serves as a trainer and facilitator in various TB diagnostics courses, participating in both national and international training activities that cover microscopy, rapid molecular diagnostics, culture, drug susceptibility testing, and related methods. 
As Section Head, Mr. Olazo oversees the development, conduct, and evaluation of TB diagnostics training courses to ensure that laboratories of the national TB laboratory network receive consistent and program-aligned learning support. He works closely with the Department of Health Centers for Health Development and other stakeholders to assess training needs, prioritize requests, and implement both NTRL-initiated and region-supported activities. He also leads his team in maintaining a roster of qualified regional trainers who conduct decentralized trainings to ensure that learning and development interventions can be delivered efficiently across the different regions of the country.

title: Ma. Teresita G. Gabriel, MD, FPDS
text:
A distinguished leader in Philippine dermatology with extensive administrative, clinical, and academic experience. She currently serves as the Head of the Leprosy Section at the Department of Dermatology, Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM), where she previously held the position of Department Chairman from 2011 to 2022.
Dr. Gabriel holds key leadership roles across several major institutions. She is the Academics Cluster Head and Active Consultant at Asian Hospital Medical Center, and the Section Head of Dermatology at both San Juan de Dios Hospital and Ospital ng Parañaque. Additionally, she ensures the ethical conduct of research as the Vice-Chair of the Institutional Review Board at San Juan de Dios Hospital.
A recognized pillar in her field, Dr. Gabriel is a Past President of the Philippine Dermatological Society (2011-2012) and the Rizal-Parañaque Medical Society (2003-2005). She continues to influence the subspecialty as an Honorary Adviser for the PDS Leprosy Subspecialty Core Group.
Beyond her clinical practice, Dr. Gabriel is a prolific scholar. She has contributed significantly to medical literature through numerous publications in local and international journals and has co-authored various book chapters in dermatology.

title: Roldan E. Bayot
text:
Mr. Roldan E. Bayot is an Entomologist III at the Department of Health – Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM), under the Medical Entomology Department, and currently serves as the Officer-in-Charge of the Insecticide Resistance Section. Since joining the Institute in 2018, he has been deeply involved in medical entomology research, with a specialized focus on insecticide resistance monitoring of mosquito-borne disease vectors. His key responsibilities include mosquito identification from routine surveillance and outbreak investigations, development of research proposals for grant funding, and the provision of technical support to both government and non-government stakeholders.
He earned his Bachelor’s Degree in Agriculture, major in Entomology, from the University of the Philippines Los Baños. His research portfolio encompasses assessing the susceptibility of Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus larvae and adults to commonly used insecticides, as well as evaluating the role of Piperonyl Butoxide (PBO) in restoring pyrethroid susceptibility and its implications for vector control strategies in the Philippines. He is also currently developing research proposals on establishing a method for the rapid assessment of insecticide formulation toxicity for program operations and investigating intergenerational resistance—efforts aimed at strengthening evidence-based public health interventions

title: Daria L. Manalo, DVM, MPH
text:
The Chief Science Research Specialist of the Veterinary Research Department (VRD) of the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM), Department of Health. She is a graduate of Veterinary Medicine at the University of the Philippines, Los Banos, and earned her master’s degree in public health at the Hebrew University, Jerusalem, Israel.
She is the head of the RITM rabies reference laboratory. She has done several research studies on rabies and animal schistosomiasis and has published papers in these fields. Currently, she is a member of the National Rabies Prevention and Control Committee. Dr. Manalo is the Chairman of the RITM Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). She conducted several training courses on rabies and the ethical use of laboratory animals in research.
She is a fellow of the Philippine College of Veterinary Public Health (PCVPH) and a diplomate of the Philippine College of Laboratory Animal Medicine (PCLAM). She is also a  member of the Philippines Association of Laboratory Animal Science (PALAS).

title: Jemelyn U. Garcia, MD
text:
Dr. Jemelyn U. Garcia is a Medical Specialist III at the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine. She is an infectious disease specialist and the Overall Training Officer and Chair of the Antimicrobial Stewardship Committee of the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine.
She is also the Antimicrobial Stewardship Committee Chair of the Asian Hospital and Medical Center. She is a diplomate and fellow of the Philippine College of Physicians and of the Philippine Society for Microbiology and Infectious Diseases.
She was a member of several technical working groups for clinical practice guidelines for Tuberculosis, COVID-19, Infection Control and Screening for Infectious Diseases.

title: Mark Kristoffer U. Pasayan, MD
text:
Dr. Pasayan, an internal medicine-infectious disease specialist at the Department of Health Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM), leads the AIDS Research Group-HIV Clinic. He obtained his medical degree from the University of the Philippines College of Medicine and completed residency training in internal medicine at The Medical City and fellowship training in infectious diseases at RITM. 
He is a fellow of the Philippine College of Physicians and a fellow and board member of the Philippine Society for Microbiology and Infectious Diseases. He is a co-primary investigator at TREAT Asia. His publications include articles in the Journal of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndromes, the Journal of the International AIDS Society, and The Lancet HIV.

title: Holly Grace Espiritu, RMT
text:
A licensed Medical Technologist and currently serves as a Senior Science Research Specialist at the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine- Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance Reference Laboratory.
She has over a decade of experience in bacteriology, national antimicrobial resistance laboratory surveillance. She also takes on the role of training officer for the Benchwork Training Course on Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing and resistance mechanism detection, where she contributes significantly to enhancing AMR diagnostic competencies across the country.
She contributes to the implementation of the ARSP External Quality Assurance Program and participates in nationwide inspections of both government and private bacteriology laboratories to ensure their adherence to accreditation standards.

title: Holly Grace Espiritu, RMT
text:
A Senior Science Research Specialist at the Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR) Surveillance Laboratory of the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM), where she has served as laboratory technical staff since 2007.
She earned her Bachelor of Science in Medical Technology from the University of Santo Tomas and further specialized by completing a diploma course in Medical Microbiology at the Institute of Medical Research in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Currently, she is enhancing her expertise by pursuing a Master’s in International Health at the University of the Philippines Open University (UPOU).
Her core technical specialization includes performing Whole Genome Sequencing (WGS) for antimicrobial-resistant bacterial pathogens, a technique she has leveraged to contribute significantly to multiple research projects and publications focused on AMR surveillance. Demonstrating a commitment to a broader public health scope, Ms. Macaranas is also deeply involved in One Health initiatives. This includes her participation in the Tricycle project, which monitors E. coli AMR across human, animal, and environmental sectors, and the TULIP project, which investigates the role of microplastics in driving AMR dissemination in aquatic settings. Her work is crucial to national surveillance and global health efforts against antimicrobial resistance.

title: June Haidee A. Lariosa
text:
A Senior Science Research Specialist at the Department of Parasitology, Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM). As part of the National Reference Laboratory, she leverages over 10 years of experience in molecular biology to lead assay development, staff training, and quality assurance. Her expertise was honed through specialized training at Smith College and the Korea CDC.
Ms. Lariosa has secured competitive funding from WHO-WPRO/TDR and RITM to drive critical research in malaria genomics and soil-transmitted helminths (STH). She is a pivotal figure in the National Malaria Therapeutic Efficacy Studies (TES) and its transition into the Integrated Drug Efficacy Surveillance (iDES) initiative. Currently piloted in Rizal and Palawan, iDES embeds efficacy monitoring into routine surveillance to enable earlier detection of treatment failures.
Furthermore, she co-leads the Philippines’ participation in the UKRI-funded DREAM-SEA project, a multi-country initiative investigating anthelmintic resistance. Through her work in genomic surveillance and AMR research, Ms. Lariosa continues to advance evidence-based strategies for national parasite control and elimination.

title: Pamela T. Tan, MD
text:
Dr. Pamela T. Tan is a dedicated Pediatric Infectious Disease Specialist. She completed her Bachelor of Science in Pharmacy and Doctor of Medicine degrees at the University of Santo Tomas (UST). Following this, she underwent her Pediatric Residency training at the UST Hospital. She further specialized by completing her Pediatric Infectious Disease Fellowship training at the University of the Philippines-Philippine General Hospital (UP-PGH).
She is a respected Diplomate of the Philippine Pediatric Society (PPS) and the Pediatric Infectious Disease Society of the Philippines (PIDSP), where she actively contributes as a member of the AMR Committee.
Currently, she serves as a Medical Specialist II and Deputy Head of the Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance Reference Laboratory at the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM).

title: Atty. Ana Liza H. Duran, MD, FPPS, MMHoA, MMPHA
text:
Dr. Ana Liza Hombrado Duran is currently the Director IV of the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM), where she oversees the Clinical, Laboratory, Biologicals Manufacturing, Administrative, and Finance Divisions. A doctor and lawyer with Master’s degrees in both Management (Major in Hospital Administration) and Public Health.
Dr. Duran brings a diverse skill set to her leadership role. She is a highly experienced professional who rose through the ranks as a practicing pediatrician to Department Chair at East Avenue Medical Center. Her past roles also include National TB Program Coordinator for Pediatrics and Chair of the Research Ethics Boards at both East Avenue Medical Center and the National Children’s Hospital. Her specific research focus is on tuberculosis in children. 
Prior to her current position, she was the RITM focal point for Chemical, Biological, Radiological, and Nuclear (CBRN) Activities, and concurrently served as Director III and Officer-in-Charge of the Biologicals Manufacturing Division. She is an active supporter of various researches on infectious and tropical diseases in RITM.

title: Lester M. Tan, MD, MPH, MSc
text:
Dr. Lester M. Tan is currently the Director IV of the Department of Health - Metro Manila Center for Health Development (DOH-MMCHD), which is the regional office of the DOH in the National Capital Region (NCR). The Office is in charge of regulating health facilities, providing assistance and coordinating with the 17 Local Government Units as well as the private sector in NCR. 
Before his transfer to DOH-MMCHD in February 2025, he served as the Director IV of the DOH Health Policy Development and Planning Bureau (HPDPB) as well as the DOH Bureau of Local Health Systems Development (BLHSD) wherein he supervised the development of national plans, policies and guidelines on the implementation of the Universal Health Care Law. Before being appointed as Director, he was a Division Chief at the BLHSD, as well as at the HPDPB. Prior to that, he was the Monitoring and Evaluation Program Manager for the Programmatic Management of Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis at the Tropical Disease Foundation, Inc, supported by the Global Fund to fight AIDS, TB and Malaria. 
He took his Bachelor’s Degree in Chemistry at the University of the Philippines Diliman, Doctor of Medicine from the University of the East Ramon Magsaysay Memorial Medical Center and has a Master’s Degree in Public Health from the University of the Philippines Manila, and a Master of Science in Global Health and Development (Health Policy) from Hanyang University in Seoul, South Korea.
